Lang explained that she was the tailor, which as I understand is different to some other shops in Hoi An as they outsource the tailoring. With so many different clothing stores popping up every second shopfront in Hoi An it can be sometimes overwhelming, having Pin Pin recommended by a friend certainly helped as I went straight there and didn't have to waste time looking for a reputable tailor. Highly recommend Lang and her store!

column6:
Prepare for me to gush: I'm a traveler, so to have found something gorgeous, elegant, and comfortable that NEVER WRINKLES was a huge huge deal for me. I bought this jumpsuit first in the silvery color and loved it so much that I immediately went back and bought it in black. It's really soft, breathable, silky material which is amazing in the tropical heat, I get SO many compliments on it, it's a jumpsuit so I never feel *over*dressed, and it's so unique, I've never seen anyone wear anything like this.

Additionally, I've also purchased 5 flowy kimonos/cover-ups from this boutique. Basically, they're my tropical-weather-wear paradise!

Lastly, the owner/designer and her staff are all so friendly and made me feel like a model when I went in to try things on. A MUST VISIT!

Now here's a barrage of pictures of me in Sinhtolina clothes!

column6: This silk is prepared with the treatment traditionally reserved for a particular era of Vietnamese emperors. Itâ€™s hand washed and sun-dried only during the early morning hours to prevent fading and saturate the silk in a special solution of black dye every day for 20 days in a row which gives the treated silk the look & drape of black leather thatâ€™s water-repellent & sun-fading resistant. Hahnsilk is the only establishment in the world that produces this treatment of silk which it fashions into classic & contemporary designs of dresses, blouses, pants, coats & capes that can be custom-fitted. The beauty of this one-of-a-kind silk fabric, once reserved only for Vietnamese emperors, is truly extraordinary, and can only be found at Hahnsilk at prices that will be appreciated by purveyors & connoisseurs of fine silk around the world.

column6:
There are 2 outlets of Sapa Hemp â€“ main store at Cau May Street and another store at the basement of Sun Plaza, same building as La Coupole Sapa where we stayed.

During my first trip to Sapa in May 2019, we spotted this shop at Sun Plaza and bought the cushion and pillow cases. At our 2nd trip in Dec 2019, we went to the main store, and bought 2 pcs of table runner and 2 coasters.

This is the most expensive gift shop in Sapa. I even heard a tourist exclaimed ~ wow wow wow wow wow ~ after asking the price. And they do not offer a single cent of discount!

Albeit pricey, we did not hesitate to buy what we loved, and you can be sure of getting the most luxurious and high quality products.

Especially the pieces with red colored hemp â€“ it feels so smooth and luxurious, it will surely wow your visitors at home. We shipped a piece of the table runner to the U.S., and my mother-in-law was very impressed with the quality.

If you would like something less expensive but good quality, check out Ahn Duc Shop which I also bought some pieces from there.

https://www.tripadvisor.com.sg/Attraction_Review-g311304-d19801108-Reviews-Anh_Duc_Shop-Sapa_Lao_Cai_Province.html

column4: 64 Quáº£ng An TÃ¢y Há»“, HÃ  Ná»™i 100000 Viá»‡t Nam
column6: For an emotional & cultural connection to the next item of clothing you buy, visit Kiomet109. From planting the seeds with women from the ethnic communities, to returning 3 months later to harvest the plants, every part of the process of making a Kilomet109 item of clothing is done by hand. Once plants are harvested the ethnic women then spin the silk or spin and weave the cotton. The materials are then dyed with indigo (another plant) or with dyes from other plants, according to secret recipes passed down by women in families, through the generations. Lots on the internet about this amazing home grown Hanoi business who has even featured in Harpers Bazaar. Great shop in Tay Ho & great story about an amazing local business with a huge social impact.

column6:
Este Boutique in Tam Coc

After dinner, we walked back to our hotel some 500 meters away when I noticed some unique items in one of the shops. If you walk by you would not even give it a second look as it looks as one of the outlets there.

However after entering, you would notice immediately that the items that they had there were very different from any other souvenir outlets. I especially am very wary of items that are at the end of the days made in China.

After browsing thru, the little lady who had a very sweet smile attended to us. Later we found out that she was the lady boss. The most interesting this was many of the items were hand made by her. Each item was slightly different even though they were replicas of the other items.

The items were all of very high quality and to have a comparison, the prices are easily 50% cheaper than what your would get in Hanoi.

I would highly recommend this place as it is unique and you would not be able to find the same items elsewhere.

Deafcraft 5 Colors provides employment for people in the Vietnamese community are deaf. This enables them to live independent lives. They create unique hangdmade cards, bookmarks, magnets, mobiles and Nativty scenes. The detail is exceptional. You will not regret visiting one of the street vendors and supporting this company.

There is a main factory or three street stall locations in Hanoi that you can visit.

The cards and gifts have a superior level of detail. We found it easy to communicate with Dat, even though he was deaf. His pop up shop is at the beginning of Ly Quoc Su. There are also pip up shops at Hang strong Street and Dinh Tien Hong Street.

column6:
I went to just over 20 shoe stores in Hoi An trying to get a very specific pair of shoes made (see picture... theyâ€™re from a YouTube video called Russian funk overload) not a single store could make them, they all immediately turned me away. Every single store I went to outsources everything and the people working donâ€™t actually know how to make the shoes so I was always told â€œno itâ€™s not possibleâ€ ...

I had given up hope and was on my way back to my hostel. Right near the western entrance of old town (by the giant sign where the 3 streets converge) I walked past a dark shop with tons of shoes outside and thought why not Iâ€™ll give it a try... I showed the lady the picture and right away she told me of course she could make them, no problem. She took my foot measurements and copies of the pictures of the shoes. I thought they were going to be terrible but I didnâ€™t care because I was essentially making them as a joke. 2 days later I stop by the shop and try them on. They fit perfect, theyâ€™re super comfy, and theyâ€™re absolutely amazing (and rediculous... which they are supposed to be). They were perfect. column6:
We visited this place during our recent HCMC trip. Taking Grab from our hotel, the journey took about 10mins (across the river via bridge) and reach this new mall! It's huge with several storeys but with only a handful of shops, cafes and restaurants operating like Watson, Miniso etc.

The key anchor is Emart, that occupies the ground floor. It's a hypermarket and on the day of our visit, it was crowded despite being a weekday, possibly because it was the eve of Christmas Eve and locals were doing their last minute shopping.

Like Carrefour or Giant, it's huge and sells a wide array of products ranging from groceries to cooked food, household, lifestyle, electrical and fashion related just to name a few. They have weekly promotions and prices were comparable to other supermarkets like AEON which we visited the day before.

We spent a couple of hours here and grabbing some local foods before heading back to our hotel in District 1.

column6: We discovered this place totally by accident. We did not intend on purchasing shoes while in Hoi An but after meeting the team at Lang Man Romantic Shoe Shop, my wife and two children (7 and 10 years old) were persuaded! We got 4 pairs of custom made shoes for around $30USD on average a pair, which I thought was reasonable, but we didn't shop around so I am not sure. We chose the style from what seemed like thousands of choices and chose the leather style and colour from another thousand choices! We paid first, which I was originally worried about, and returned the next day to find all of the team there to greet us while we each tried on our brand-new shoes. They fit perfectly and seemed to be well-made (I will write again in a couple of months to update on how they have lasted). Thank you for a wonderful experience that we will remember for a lifetime!

column6: Spotted this by chance and was very glad I did. I am a UK size 16 and 5'10" so clothes shopping in South East Asia is difficult. Equally I am backpacking so the idea of getting tailor made clothes that I will destroy is somewhat off putting. However the standard 'tourist clothes' neither look that good, fit well and most importantly don't last more than about a month on me. Thus my need for some better clothes. The owner (I think) was very nice here, not pushy but helpful in finding stuff which would actually fit me. I was at the larger end of his clothing range however UK sizes 14 (so US 12 and Auz 16) and below sould have plenty of choice. Women's clothes only but a range of trousers, tops, skirts, and mainly dresses. The trousers I got were 250000 D each and the dress was 350000 D (with the prices labelled). Which as I saw similar dresses for 800000 D seems pretty good. The clothing appears to be well made with nice fabric (the dress was 50%cotton and 50%silk, the trousers 100% cotton), though time will tell how long they will survive the intended abuse they will suffer. Most the clothing was of the smart casual type so probably something there for most occasions. Also, despite the name, though there were lots of embroidery (which he did in the shop), many pieces didn't have any on if that's not your style. Well worth a visit in any case if you're in Hanoi and easily located near Hoan Kiem Lake and St Joseph Cathedral.

Neither happened. Unfortunately they had me come back so late to get the finished products that they couldnâ€™t change anything then and I was leaving very early the next morning- which she knew and I think why she had me come back so late. column6:
Tracy Decor
In Ho Chi Minh City, in Vietnam, Tracy Decor is simply the best interior designer,
and that for about 8 years already.
Unsurprisingly, I can only favorably recommend their services.

Having decorated some of the best known Â«in-restaurantsÂ» and bars in town,
their main activity is interior decoration and furniture for houses and apartments,
from nice upper-end to super luxury. You will never get things done that fast.
Nor will You be able find all the stuff they can, the lamps, carpets and curtains
that they can find with a phone call, You will spend days, and still not get what
You wanted, and certainly never for the price they get. So to sum it up, if You
are looking to re-decorate Your existing home, partially or completely, or to fully decorate Your new house or apartment in Vietnam, I can only recommend
Tracy Decor in the highest possible terms.

column6:
I'm a businessman from America, travelling in Hanoi. I had heard that tailors in the area would make custom suits, and seeing many well dressed Vietnamese and Chinese around the city, I was inclined to believe the rumors and seek out a good tailor for a fair price.

I had a Vietnamese speaking guide, who took me around to several shops. I know a lot of work goes into making a custom suit, and that a skilled tailor should be compensated well, but at the same time I wanted to get a fair price that was reflective of the local market - not the "tourist" price.

I ended up at a small shop named Nguyen Nam. I It is located on 72 Hang Ga street. The owner is a middle aged distinguished looking gentlemen, whom I presume is Mr. Nguyen himself. (He dressed like a golfer - and sure enough - proudly displayed a picture of himself on the greens. His handicap is a +7, not bad, especially as gold is a relatively new sport in Vietnam, and he'd only been playing a year. But I digress...)

I sat down with his female staff and looked at several hardcover fashion books, displaying the latest trends. They also brought out a laptop, with image files of famous actors in suits - Daniel Craig, Brad Pitt, Leo DiCaprio, George Clooney - they all made an appearance. Once I'd settled on the type of suit I wanted (two button, modern fit, slim breasted, shorter coat, no cuffs on the pants), I picked the material. As with most tailor shops, Mr. Nguyen had his materials hanging on the wall, and I stood in front of a mirror and had my guide take pictures as he held up each material to my body to see which color was the best. (Note: as I am slightly color blind, and the natural light in Hanoi can be lacking during the cloudy season, my guide offered to take a picture of me on her phone; it gave me a much better idea of the coloring of the fabric against my skin than the fluorescent shop lights.)

Finally, I picked the fabric: a deep blue. He quoted me the price, and I attempted a weak counter offer, but Mr. Nguyen was firm - $380. (I could have probably bargained him down, but I have no backbone for hard negotiations, and I rationalized his price as a better deal than a custom suit in the US, although I probably would have ordered two suits if he had offered a discount to $300 a suit.) I also decided on a second suit jacket of a different color and less expensive material, that he quoted me at $160, all in all I paid around $540 for a custom suit plus extra jacket. He said he would have them ready in five days, but that I would have to come back in two days to test the fit.

Well, I went back last night to test the fit, again with my guide. Everything looked marvelous. I had him give me a little extra room in the legs and shoulders - I'm a largish man, at 6'2" and 212lbs, and I didn't want to burst the seams on my new custom suit. However, I was so pleased with his work, I ordered a second suit, this time in black. Now that he had my measurements, he said he could have it ready at the same time as my other suits. All told, I dropped almost $900, for two custom suits and a blazer. While expensive, I look at it as an investment that will last for the next 3-5 years, and will pay off in spades as "perception is reality" in the business world, and the reality is, Mr. Nguyen's suits look and feel great.

Final thoughts:

- Bring a cell phone with a currency converter, so you can make sure you are paying a fair price.
- Hire a translator or guide. It makes a huge difference! But don't assume that just because the shop owner chooses to speak to your translator in Vietnamese, that they don't understand English. Be careful what you say: always be respectful, this is their profession, and they are very proud of it.
- Be extremely specific about what you want. Don't leave anything open to interpretation. Once you purchase a custom suit, it's pretty hard to come back to get it altered, if you aren't living in Hanoi or make frequent visits.

column6:
Nha trang is famous for swift bird. There are 2 places on Nha trang which you can see them. One is the Swift bird island and this one is called " Nha Yen " (Swift bird house).
It was called " Nha yen "because the bird came to make nest and live here naturally.
The bird leave to find food early in the morning (5-6am) and return to the house at (5-6pm).
The house provide a free entrance to introduce you about the bird house, the product ... but only in Vietnamese, so you should go with a local or a tour guide for translation. The staffs also provide a small cup of tea which made of the bird nest (after cooking).
The bird nest is good for your health and you can buy it here as a gift for your friends and famliy.

I got a superb custom made cashmere wool suit, silk shirt and matching bow tie for 145$. To say i am highly satisfied is an understatement,i will be the smartest guy at the wedding thanks
to PEACE TAILORS--big thank you.

column6: We went there and they highly recomended this vape as the the seller said she had one before. We spent 2 million on two vapes and liquids. After couple hours liquid from both vapes was leaking into our mouths when using it. We went back the next day and explained the problem. First they said it was a problem with all these models. When i asked why they didnt tell me that when i boight it they tried to give us two different excuses 1) We have to use every 3 hours, which makes no sense cause i cant use it when im sleeping and 2) the cartarige was filled too much - they filled it when we bought it. We agreed after giving us a new cartarige and filling a little that if the problem continued we could exchange it. The problem continued and we went back the next day only for them to deny that it was leaking. They then said we had have to breathe in sofly or itd leak. Another terrible excuse. They refused us a refund or even an exchange. In summary, they sold us a faulty vape, then lied to us and made excuses about it, and refused us an exchange after agreeing they would.

column4: 87 Hang Gai Str, HÃ  Ná»™i 10000 Viá»‡t Nam
column6: We spent considerable time trying to locate a store that had laquerware and figurines that were better than Vanloi's, and we couldn't find anything. We stopped at several stores near our hotel, the Sheraton, and also at stores enroute to Ha Long Bay. Vanloi's selection and quality for what we were looking for, at least, were unmatched. The prices were not crazy expensive, either. Vanloi sells a lot of beautiful laquerware trays, decorative boxes and containers, and figures, mostly wood, some ceramic, as well as fantastic large furniture pieces--wardrobes, chests, and so on, all very nicely made. I see the other review that mentioned shipping issues. Vanloi actually helped us assemble a large box, which then fit into another box (double box, a good idea!), and we packed everything carefully and checked the box as second luggage on our return flights home; the two airlines we used, SIA and Asiana, had no issue with it. If I ever went back to Vietnam, I would definitely shop Vanloi. In fact, we are going to order some items from them because we wish we'd bought more.

column6:
We have known Leo at Thu Thuy for almost ten years now having booked trips and bought many custom-made clothes from him on our various trips to Vietnam. The clothes included suits, shorts, dresses, jackets, and shirts, all of which were good quality at a great price. Although you can buy cheap suits now in Australia they are off the rack and never fit as good as custom-made clothes.

As the other reviewer here notes, Leoâ€™s English is very good which makes for fewer misunderstandings, which happen often in Vietnam! That then leaves you little time to correct if you are not in town for long or will cost you extra money to fix. If itâ€™s a mix-up with tours then you may miss out altogether and get no refund.

Although Leo operates out of a little shop, he can arrange or make almost anything you want and goes out of his way to ensure you are happy with his services and products. Unfortunately he does not have a website, nor does he promote his services in any way so itâ€™s all word of mouth.

However, he does tour the streets of Cua Dai Beach on his motorbike at various times drumming up business with tourists. You may run into him if you're eating dinner at one of the many local cafes in Cua Dai Beach: you'll know itâ€™s him as he has one eye which turns out a touch. Iâ€™m sure Leo wonâ€™t mind me saying that as he says it makes him distinctive!

column6:
Persoonlijk vind ik onderhandelen erg lastig en ongemakkelijk, maar omdat ik telkens dezelfde jas tegen kwam die me erg aansprak qua model waagde ik me toch een winkel in. Deze winkel had namelijk het model, maar dan zonder de knoopjes op de sluiting. Passen ging met weinig enthousiasme, wel in woorden, maar het straalde er niet vanaf. Kleur kiezen, voering etc. Ze proberen redelijk met je mee te praten. Maar er straalde weinig echte vriendelijkheid vanaf. Met het onderhandelen ging het niet anders. Maar moet gezegd dus ook niet mijn sterkste punt. Maar het ging zoals ons eerder was verteld, als je wegloopt roepen ze je alsnog terug als je niet hebt ondergeboden. Toch probeerden ze er nog een paar dollar bij te kletsen. En uiteindelijk met het omrekenen naar Dong ( ik had geen dollars om mee te betalen) bleek ik achteraf toch nog een 1 dollar meer te hebben betaald. Dat heb ik zo gelaten. De volgende middag terug om te passen! De beide dames keken nog steeds niet erg vriendelijk. Er kon geen lachje vanaf. De jas was klaar. Maat was prima! Keurig afgewerkt. Wel kleine oneffenheid aan de binnenkant bij de voering. Verder super leuk om zo je jas te laten maken op kleur!
Ik had een deel betaald, en betaalde nu het laatste deel. Kreeg ik te weinig wisselgeld terug. Deed ze heel moeilijk over. Werd voor mij meer een principe kwestie. Toen kwam er toch 5000 en uiteindelijk ook nog de resterende 3000. Toen ik daarna wegging en vriendelijk bedankte en lachte, kwam er een miniem lachje terug.

column4: 92 Nguyá»…n Há»¯u Cáº£nh 4 D7 Saigon Pearl Villa, BÃ¬nh Tháº¡nh, ThÃ nh phá»‘ Há»“ ChÃ­ Minh 700000 Viá»‡t Nam
column6:
Visited SIR Tailor many months back when they were at their old location. Iâ€™ve tailored at many different places - particularly in Singapore and in Hong Kong (Samâ€™s Tailors/WW Chan). So hereâ€™s the good and the bad: when I compare SIR against the other tailors that I have patronised. Unfortunately SIR is the only Vietnamese tailor that I have visited, so I canâ€™t say for the other tailors.

Good
===
1. I think tailoring (or at least premium style ones) is still at its infancy stage in Vietnam so SIR is about educating the masses.
2. Clothes were on time - they promised 1 week for shirts to be delivered.
3. I only visited once to choose the fabrics and get my measurements done - they were excellent - that I wonâ€™t deny.

Bad
===
1. Expensive when it comes to the â€œpremiumâ€ fabrics, premium in this case relates solely to Thomas Mason fabrics. Perhaps the label of TM should be affixed to the shirt for authenticity purposes.
2. Limited range of fabrics - you get a lot of local/Chinese fabrics off unbranded fabric swatches books. - perhaps the need to look at getting Soktas etc.
3. Overseas shipping incurs hefty charges - other tailors would gladly ship for free. No tracking number too.
4. The old location was a bit small but I hear they have since moved - so maybe thatâ€™s a bad point that has now changed to good.
5. Service was a bit slow - they took a while to serve - they was another American couple there at the same time who seemed a bit impatient.

I was recently in Hanoi and brought a top and dress. Once I returned to the US and tried my dress on for the first time, the entire elastic around the shoulders snapped and the dress immediately fell down to my waist. The dress is not wearable, it is completely broken at the top as the elastic is not holding up.

A friend I was traveling with also bought a different dress from this store and the strap broke the first night she wore it. We were still in Hanoi at the time and I believe the store did exchange it for her.

I reached out to request a refund since Iâ€™m not able to return or exchange in person and the store declined.

column6:
VietNam's Delights is a chain of shops selling Vietnamese and produce from many other countries. Such as Cola from the US and Nestle from France.

The prices are exorbitant and the service is terrible.

At VD at NoiBai (Hanoi) international airport, foreigners are charged 98,000 Dong for 2 small CocaColas that usually cost 20,000 Dong.

Yes, I understand that things cost more at airports. But 5 times more is a ripoff.

When I said "Oh my god! Really 98k?" the staff and I had a great laugh. They know it is a ridiculous ripoff.

Summary: Stay away

But this soon turned out to be a NIGHTMARE! This was without a doubt the most expensive place we had clothing (primarily shirts) made and the service was terrible. Nothing was done in time and never according to our wishes. The staff there was also calling us names in vietnamese (they didn't know that I understood vietnamese). So making 2 shirts took us 3 days with argueing and on the last day the owner threatened to call the police since we didn't want to pay the remaining 50% of the price for what we had ordered. With this treath in mind we paid for the shirts even though the quality and tailoring was bad, so that we could continue on our beach vacation. I have never in all of my years of travelling had such a bad experience in a shop ever. So if you read this review please stay away!

column6: Despite having a nicely done website, the store is an absolute joke. I was trying to buy a dining table and went into the shop to see the material in person only to find out that they didn't have samples to check out. I asked them how do they expect to sell anything without any displays? With a non-existent return policy in Vietnam, don't they think consumers would want to see what they are buying before they make a purchase especially on expensive items!? Messages through their Facebook go unanswered even though they have seen the message. That should be enough to tell you what kind of operation they are running! Stay away if you don't want any headaches!

column6: SHOCKINGLY BAD LEATHER PRODUCT MAKERS, the older rude Vietnamese woman in the shop wanted payment before making anything, I gave her way over what I should have paid (advised by 3 local Vietnamese friends that she had ripped me off!) for a wallet, the card section did not work for slotting cards in, plus bad, uneven stitching, then the glasses case which was flimsy not suitable for protecting glasses and button hole warped stretched leather, then the bag (OH MY!) tacky, badly stitched with glue left around the stitching! All the products were terribly made, and no refund was given even after asking and going into the shop to get the products fixed, nothing was fixed and handed back to me. The worst part was she PUSHED and HIT ME when I asked her for a refund! I was totally shocked! I could not believe a person would do this, how unstable, violent, and aggressive this woman was, she took no responsibility for hitting and pushing me, or even give me a partial refund for badly made items! DO NOT BUY ANYTHING FROM THIS SHOP, THEY ARE LIARS, THEFTS, AGGRESSIVE AND UNSTABLE! I was told by several people in Hoi An that they would not use B199, as they charge way over what should be charged, unfortunately I trusted them. I'm getting my story out and letting people know not to go in, many better and honest shops around Hoi An. This woman is a disgrace to Vietnam.

column6: My Mom bought 4 sculptures here when she came back to Vietnam and visited Da Nang. column6: I should have read the reviews first! I chose a beautiful fabric and negotiated a price with the tailor which was on the high side. She insisted I pay the whole amount up front. Two days later she called me and said I had to come back to the store and pick another fabric as she didnâ€™t have the one I had picked. I had to change my plans for the day to travel back to the store and pick an inferior fabric to the one I had paid for. Despite returning for three more fittings and adjustments the suit pants were miles too big and I had to have them taken in when I got home to Australia. The woman was also very rude to my brother and demanded he pay an extra $30 (US) on top of what he had already paid for a jacket because she said the buttons were too expensive. My sister also had four fittings for her dress and it still wasnâ€™t right and had to pay for it to be fixed in Hoi An. Quality of workmanship is the only good thing I can say unfortunately.
